holidays.name: International Dot Day
holidays.description: A creative celebration inspired by a children's book encouraging people to embrace their creativity and courage through making marks and 'dots.'
holidays.origin: Based on Peter H. Reynolds's book 'The Dot,' International Dot Day started in 2009 as a way to encourage creativity and self-expression in schools worldwide.
holidays.funFact: Schools in over 185 countries participate each year by creating art projects and sharing their 'dots' online!

holidays.name: National Double Cheeseburger Day
holidays.description: A delicious day dedicated to celebrating the mouthwatering joy of double cheeseburgers piled high with cheese and patties.
holidays.origin: Created by burger lovers and popularized by food enthusiasts, this day is unofficial but widely recognized by burger joints and fans alike.
holidays.funFact: The first known double cheeseburger dates back to the 1930s, making this indulgent treat nearly a century old!

holidays.name: International Day of Democracy
holidays.description: An observance dedicated to promoting and upholding the principles of democracy around the globe, highlighting the importance of citizen participation and human rights.
holidays.origin: Established by the United Nations in 2007 to encourage awareness and respect for democratic processes worldwide.
holidays.funFact: This day is marked by events like debates, discussions, and voting awareness campaigns globally.

holidays.name: Engineering Week (start)
holidays.description: Some regions kick off a week-long celebration of engineering achievements starting on this date, honoring innovators and inspiring future engineers.
holidays.origin: Various engineering societies and institutions organize events during this week to boost STEM education and celebrate engineering milestones.
holidays.funFact: Engineering Week often features challenges that have participants build bridges from unusual materials or design Rube Goldberg machines!
